column73: Senator.Lets turn it over to Errol Lewis
column74: of New York 1 Time Warner Cable News.LOUIS: Secretary Clinton
column75: the 1994 crime bill that you supported added 100
column76: 000 police officers across the country and banned certain assault weapons. It also imposed tougher prison sentences and eliminated federal funding for inmate education.Looking at the bill as a whole
column77: do you believe it was a net positive or do you think it was a mistake?CLINTON: Well
column78: I think that it had some positive aspects to it. And you mentioned some of them. The Violence Against Women Act
column79: which has been a very important piece of legislation
column80: in my opinion.(APPLAUSE)CLINTON: And it also did some things which were to provide more opportunities for young people. So if we were to have the balance sheet on one side
column81: there are some positive actions and changes.On the other side
column82: there were decisions that were made that now we must revisit and we have to correct. I think that sentences got much too long. The original idea was not that we would increase sentences for non-violent low-level offenders
column83: but once the federal government did what it did
column84: states piled on.So we have a problem. And the very first speech I gave in this campaign was about what I will do to reform the criminal justice system and end the over-mass incarceration.So I think that if all of us go and look back at where we were
column85: Senator Sanders voted for the crime bill
column86: and he says the same thing
column88: and things that we have to change and learn from.So thats how I see it. And I think we ought to be putting our attention on forging a consensus to make the changes that will divert more people from the criminal justice system to start.LOUIS: Thank you
column89: Secretary.CLINTON: To tackle systemic racism and divert people in the beginning.LOUIS: Now earlier this year
column90: a South Carolina voter told your daughter Chelsea
column92: I think a lot of African-Americans want to hear
column94: we made a mistake. Chelsea said she has heard you apologize
column95: but went on to say that if the voter hadnt heard it then
column97: its clearly insufficient.Do you regret your advocacy for the crime bill?CLINTON: Well
column99: I supported the crime bill. My husband has apologized. He was the president who actually signed it
column100: Senator Sanders...LOUIS: But what about you
column101: Senator?CLINTON: ... voted for it. Im sorry for the consequences that were unintended and that have had a very unfortunate impact on peoples lives.Ive seen the results of what has happened in families and in communities.CLINTON: Thats why I chose to make my very first speech a year ago on this issue
column103: because I want to focus the attention of our country and to make the changes we need to make. And I also want people...(APPLAUSE)... especially I want  I want white people  I want white people to recognize that there is systemic racism. Its also in employment
column105: but it is in the criminal justice system
column107: earlier this week at the Apollo Theater in Harlem
column108: you called out President Clinton for defending Secretary Clintons use of the term super-predator back in the 90s when she supported the crime bill. Why did you call him out?SANDERS: Because it was a racist term
column109: and everybody knew it was a racist term.(APPLAUSE)Look
column110: much of what Secretary Clinton said was right. We had a crime bill. I voted for it. It had the Violence Against Women Act in it. When as mayor of Burlington
column111: we worked very hard to try to eliminate domestic violence. This took us a good step forward. Were talking about the weapon that killed the children in Sandy Hook. This banned assault weapons
column112: not insignificant.But where we are today is we have a broken criminal justice system. We have more people in jail than any other country on Earth. And in my view
column113: what we have got to do is rethink the system from the bottom on up. And that means
column114: for a start  and we dont talk about this. The media doesnt talk about it  you got 51 percent of African-American kids today who graduated high school who are unemployed or underemployed. You know what I think? Maybe we invest in jobs and education for those kids
column115: not jails and incarceration.(APPLAUSE)And Ill tell you what else. And Ill tell you what else I think. And that is
column116: we have got  and this is the difference between the secretary and myself as I understand it. We have got to have the guts to rethink the so-called war on drugs. Too many lives... BLITZER: Thank you
column117: Senator.SANDERS: Too many lives have been destroyed because people possessed marijuana
column118: millions over a 30-year period. And that is why I believe we should take marijuana out of the federal Controlled Substance Act.(APPLAUSE)LOUIS: Thank you. Thank you. Lets  lets get Secretary Clintons response.CLINTON: Well
column121: as Senator Sanders said about what I said
column122: I will say about what he said. I think that we recognize that we have a set of problems that we cannot ignore and we must address. And that is why I have been promoting for my entire adult life
column124: the idea of investing early in kids
column127: like what Mayor de Blasio brought to New York. We have got to help more kids get off to a good start. Thats why I want a good teacher in a good school for every child
column128: regardless of the ZIP Code that child lives in...LOUIS: Thank you. Thank you
column129: Secretary Clinton.(APPLAUSE)CLINTON: ... and to be really focused on how we build ladders of opportunity and tear down these barriers that stand in the way of people getting ahead.LOUIS: Your times up
column131: I have a question for you related to this. So youve said that by the end of your first term as president
column132: the U.S. will no longer lead the world in mass incarceration. To fulfill that promise
column133: youd have to release roughly half a million prisoners. How are you going to do that
column134: since the vast majority of American prisoners are not under federal jurisdiction?SANDERS: Were going to work with state governments all over this country. And you know what? In a very divided Congress
column135: and a very divided politics in America
column136: actually the one area where there is some common ground is conservatives understand that its insane to be spending $80 billion a year locking up 2.2 million people.With federal and presidential leadership
column137: we will work with state governments to make sure that people are released from jail under strong supervision
column138: that they get the kind of job training and education they need so they can return to their communities. On this one
column140: actually I think youre going to see progressive and conservative support. We can do it
column141: if were prepared to be bold.BLITZER: Thank you
column143: Secretary. We have to take a quick commercial break. We have a lot more questions for Secretary Clinton and Senator Sanders right after this.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)BLITZER: Welcome back.Lets turn to another critically important issue.Senator
column145: the issue of energy and the environment.Secretary Clinton
column146: Senator Sanders has said you are in the pocket of the fossil fuel industry. You say youre sick and tired of him lying about your record.What are his lies?CLINTON: Well
column147: let me start by saying we need to talk about this issue and we should talk about it in terms of the extraordinary threats that climate change pose to our country and our world. And thats why for the last many years
column148: both in the Senate and as secretary of State
column149: its been a big part of my commitment to see what could be done.But there has never been any doubt that when I was a senator
column150: I tried  I joined with others to try to get rid of the subsidies for big oil. And I have proposed that again
column151: because thats what I think needs to be done as we transition from fossil fuels to clean energy.CLINTON: And everyone whos looked at this independently
column153: who give us both hard times when called for on facts
column154: have said that this is absolutely an incorrect false charge.So
column155: we both have relatively small amounts of contributions from people who work for fossil fuel companies. Best we can tell from the reports that are done.But
column156: that is not being supported by big oil
column157: and I think its important to distinguish that. And
column158: lets talk about what each of us has proposed to try to combat greenhouse gas emissions and put us on the fastest track possible to clean energy.BLITZER: Thank you. Were going to get to that to
column159: but I want you to respond
column162: to talk about workers. Im sure I have contributions
column163: you have contributions from workers in every industry in the country. But
column165: 43 lobbyists for the fossil fuel industry maxed out
column166: gave the maximum amount of money to Secretary Clintons campaign.(APPLAUSE)SANDERS: Now
column170: given the hundreds of millions of dollars she raises its a small amount. Thats true. But
column171: that does not mean to say that the lobbyists thought she was a pretty good bet on this issue.Now
column172: what I think is when we look at climate change now
column173: we have got to realize that this is a global environmental crisis of unprecedented urgency.(APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)And
column174: it is not good enough. You know
column177: were attacked tomorrow the whole country would rise up and say we got an enemy out there and we got to do something about it. That was what 9/11 was about.We have an enemy out there
column178: and that enemy is going to cause drought and floods and extreme weather disturbances. Theres going to be international conflict.(APPLAUSE) I am proud
column180: that I have introduced the most comprehensive climate change legislation...BLITZER: .... Thank you...SANDERS: ... Including a tax on carbon. Something I dont believe Secretary Clinton supports.(APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)BLITZER: Secretary Clinton
column182: lets talk about the global environmental crisis. Starting in 2009 as your Secretary of State
column183: I worked with President Obama to bring China and India to the table for the very first time
column184: to get a commitment out of them that they would begin to address their own greenhouse gas emissions.(APPLAUSE)I continued to work on that throughout the four years as Secretary of State
column185: and I was very proud that President Obama and America led the way to the agreement that was finally reached in Paris with 195 nations committing to take steps to actually make a difference in climate change.(APPLAUSE)And
column186: I was surprised and disappointed when Senator Sanders attacked the agreement
column188: it didnt go far enough. You know
column189: at some point putting together 195 countries
column190: I know a little bit about that
column191: was a major accomplishment...BLITZER: ... Thank you...(APPLAUSE CHEERING)CLINTON: ... And
column192: our President led the effort to protect our world and he deserve our appreciation
column194: Senator...SANDERS: ... Lets talk about that. When you were Secretary of State
column195: you also worked hard to expand fracking to countries all over the world.(CHEERING)SANDERS: The issue here  of course the agreement is a step forward
column196: but you know agreements and I know agreements
column197: theres a lot of paper there. Weve got to get beyond paper right now.We have got to lead the world in transforming our energy system
column202: it means having the guts to take on the fossil fuel industry. Now
column203: I am on board legislation that says
column205: we aint going to excavate for fossil fuel on public land. Thats not Secretary Clintons position.BLITZER: Thank you.Let us support a tax on carbon...BLITZER: ... Secretary Clinton...SANDERS: ... Not Secretary Clintons position.BLITZER: ... Go ahead and respond.(APPLAUSE)CLINTON: Well
column206: Im a little bewildered about how to respond when you have an agreement which gives you the framework to actually take the action that would have only come about because under the Obama administration in the face of implacable hostility from the Republicans in Congress
column207: President Obama moved forward on gas mileage
column208: he moved forward on the clean power plant. He has moved forward on so many of the fronts that he could given the executive actions that he was able to take.(APPLAUSE)And
column210: I am getting a little bit  Im getting a little bit concerned here because
column212: I really believe that the President has done an incredible job against great odds and deserves to be supported.(APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)CLINTON: Now
column213: its easy  its easy to diagnose the problem. Its harder to do something about the problem. And...(APPLAUSE)BLITZER: Thank you
column214: Secretary. Well continue on this. Errol  Errol Louis
column215: go ahead with your question.SANDERS: Wolf. Wolf.BLITZER: Were going to continue on this. Errol
column218: you also pioneered a program to promote fracking around the world
column221: a way of extracting natural gas. Now as a candidate for president
column222: you say that by the time youre done with all your rules and regulations
column223: fracking will be restricted in many places around the country. Why have you changed your view on fracking?CLINTON: No
column225: I dont think Ive changed my view on what we need to do to go from where we are
column226: where the world is heavily dependent on coal and oil
column228: to where we need to be
column230: and one of the bridge fuels is natural gas.And so for both economic and environmental and strategic reasons
column231: it was American policy to try to help countries get out from under the constant use of coal
column232: building coal plants all the time
column233: also to get out from under
column234: especially if they were in Europe
column236: which has been incredibly intense. So we did say natural gas is a bridge. We want to cross that bridge as quickly as possible
column237: because in order to deal with climate change
column238: we have got to move as rapidly as we can.Thats why Ive set big goals. I want to see us deploy a half a billion more solar panels by the end of my first term and enough clean energy to provide electricity to every home in America within 10 years.(APPLAUSE)So I have big
column240: but I know in order to get from where we are
column241: where the world is still burning way too much coal
column242: where the world is still too intimidated by countries and providers like Russia
column243: we have got to make a very firm but decisive move in the direction of clean energy.LOUIS: Thank you
column246: here is  here is a real difference. This is a difference between understanding that we have a crisis of historical consequence here
column247: and incrementalism and those little steps are not enough.(APPLAUSE)Not right now. Not on climate change. Now
column250: Secretary Clinton actively supported fracking technology around the world. Second of all
column252: we have got to tell the fossil fuel industry that their short-term profits are not more important than the future of this planet.(APPLAUSE)And that means  and I would ask you to respond. Are you in favor of a tax on carbon so that we can transit away from fossil fuel to energy efficiency and sustainable energy at the level and speed we need to do?(APPLAUSE)CLINTON: You know
column253: I have laid out a set of actions that build on what President Obama was able to accomplish
column254: building on the clean power plan
column255: which is currently under attack by fossil fuels and the right in the Supreme Court
column256: which is one of the reasons why we need to get the Supreme Court justice that President Obama has nominated to be confirmed so that we can actually continue to make progress.I dont take a back seat to your legislation that youve introduced that you havent been able to get passed. I want to do what we can do to actually make progress in dealing with the crisis. Thats exactly what I have proposed.LOUIS: OK
column258: Secretary Clinton.CLINTON: And my approach I think is going to get us there faster without tying us up into political knots with a Congress that still would not support what you are proposing.(CROSSTALK)LOUIS: Senator Sanders
column259: youve said that climate change is the greatest change to our nations security.SANDERS: Secretary Clinton did not answer one simple question.LOUIS: Excuse me
column264: Senator...SANDERS: Are you for a tax on carbon or not? LOUIS: I have a question for you. Youve said that climate change is the greatest threat to our nations security. Youve called for a nationwide ban on fracking. Youve also called for phasing out all nuclear power in the U.S. But wouldnt those proposals drive the country back to coal and oil
column265: and actually undermine your fight against global warming?SANDERS: No
column267: heres where we are. Let me reiterate. We have a global crisis. Pope Francis reminded us that we are on a suicide course. Our legislation understands
column269: that there will be economic dislocation. It is absolutely true. There will be some people who lose their job. And we build into our legislation an enormous amount of money to protect those workers. It is not their fault...SANDERS: It is not their fault that fossil fuels are destroying our climate.But we have got to stand up and say right now
column270: as we would if we were attacked by some military force
column271: we have got to move urgency  urgently and boldly.What does that mean?UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Senator  senator
column272: jobs...SANDERS: Yes?UNIDENTIFIED MALE:  jobs are one thing
column273: but with less than 6 percent of all U.S. energy coming from solar
column275: and 20 percent of U.S. power coming from nuclear
column276: if you phase out all of that
column277: how do you make up...SANDERS: Well
column278: you dont phase...UNIDENTIFIED MALE:  that difference?SANDERS:  it all out tomorrow. And you certainly dont phase nuclear out tomorrow. But this is what you do do.(APPLAUSE)SANDERS: What you do do is say that we are going to have a massive program  and I had introduced  introduced legislation for 10 million solar rooftops. We can put probably millions of people to work retrofitting and weatherizing buildings all over this country.(CHEERING)SANDERS: Saving  rebuilding our rail system.(APPLAUSE)SANDERS: Our mass transit system.(APPLAUSE)SANDERS: If we approach this
column280: as if we were literally at a war  you know
column284: within three more years to rebuild our economy to defeat Nazism and Japanese imperialism. That is exactly the kind of approach we need right now.BLITZER: Thank you.(APPLAUSE)SANDERS: Lead the world.BLITZER: Thank you
column285: Senator.(APPLAUSE)BLITZER: Lets turn to another critically important issue...(APPLAUSE)BLITZER:  the issue of national security and foreign policy.Secretary Clinton
column286: President Obama says the worst mistake in office that he made over these past seven and a half years was not preparing for Libya after Moammar Qadafi was removed. You were his secretary of State.Arent you also responsible for that?CLINTON: Well
column287: let me say I think we did a great deal to help the Libyan people after Qadafis demise. And heres what we did.We helped them hold two successful elections
column289: which they did very well because they had a pent up desire to try to chart their own future after 42 years of dictatorship.I was very proud of that.We got rid of the chemical weapons stockpile that Qadafi had
column291: getting it away from militias or terrorist groups.We also worked to help them set up their government. We sent a lot of American experts there. We offered to help them secure their borders
column294: when it came to security issues
column296: did not want troops from any other country
column299: in Libya.And so we were caught in a very difficult position. They could not provide security on their own
column300: which we could see and we told them that
column301: but they didnt want to have others helping to provide that security.And the result has been a clash between different parts of the country
column302: terrorists taking up some locations in the country.And we cant walk away from that. We need to be working with European and Arab partners...BLITZER: Thank you.CLINTON:  with the United Nations in order to continue to try to support them.The Libyan people deserve a chance at democracy and self- government. And I
column304: will keep trying to give that to themBLITZER: Senator
column305: go ahead.SANDERS: According to The New York Times...(APPLAUSE)SANDERS:  for President Obama
column306: this was a pretty tough call
column311: was a horrific dictator?The New York Times told us it was Secretary Clinton who led the effect for that regime change. And this is the same type of mentality that supported the war in Iraq.(APPLAUSE)SANDERS: Look...(APPLAUSE)SANDERS:  Qadafi
column313: brutal murdering thugs. No debate about that.But what we have got to do and what the president was saying is we didnt think thoroughly about what happens the day after you get rid of these dictators.Regime change often has unintended consequences in Iraq and in Libya right now
column314: where ISIS has a very dangerous foothold. And I think if you studied the whole history of...BLITZER: Yes.SANDERS:  American involvement in regime change
column315: you see that quite often.BLITZER: Secretary
column316: were going to let you respond.(APPLAUSE)CLINTON: Yes
column318: I...(APPLAUSE)CLINTON:  I...(APPLAUSE)CLINTON:  I  I would just point out that there was a vote in the Senate as to whether or not the United States should support the efforts by the Libyan people to protect themselves against the threats
column319: the genocidal threats coming from Gadhafi
column320: and whether we should go to the United Nations to seek Security Council support.Senator sanders voted for that
column321: and thats exactly what we did.SANDERS: No.(CROSSTALK)CLINTON: We went to the United Nations  yes
column322: he did. We went to the United Nations Security Council. We got support from the Security Council. And we then supported the efforts of our European and Arab allies and partners.This was a request made to our government by the Europeans and by the Arabs because of their great fear of what chaos in Syria would do to them. And if you want to know what chaos does
column323: not just to the people inside but the people on the borders
column324: look at Syria.Nobody stood up to Assad and removed him
column325: and we have had a far greater disaster in Syria than we are currently dealing with right now in Libya.(APPLAUSE)(CROSSTALK)BLITZER: Senator
column326: go ahead.SANDERS: Secretary Clinton made this charge in previous debates and just repeating it doesnt make it truer. What you are talking about is what I think was what they call the unanimous consent
column329: do we support Libya moving to democracy?Well
column331: I surely have always supported Libya moving to democracy. But please do not confuse that with your active effort for regime change without contemplating what happened the day after. Totally different issue.CLINTON: Well
column332: that isnt...SANDERS: Second of all  second of all
column337: then well get to that.Go ahead
column338: Secretary.CLINTON: There was also in that a reference to the Security Council
column339: and I know youre not shy when you oppose something
column342: it was unanimous. Thats exactly right
column343: including you.And what we did was to try to provide support for our European and Arab allies and partners. The decision was the presidents. Did I do the due diligence? Did I talk to everybody I could talk to? Did I visit every capital and then report back to the president? Yes
column344: I did. Thats what a secretary of state does.But at the end of the day
column345: those are the decisions that are made by the president to in any way use American military power. And the president made that decision. And
column347: we did try without success because of the Libyans obstruction to our efforts
column348: but we did try and we will continue to try to help the Libyan people.BLITZER: Thank you
column351: you know  two points. Number one
column353: 100-0 in the Senate voted for democracy in Libya and I would vote for that again. But that is very different from getting actively involved to overthrow and bring about regime change without fully understanding what the consequence of that regime change would be.Second of all
column354: I know you keep referring to Barack Obama all night here
column356: you in Syria talked about a no-fly zone
column357: which the president certainly does not support
column360: it will cost an enormous sum of money
column362: it runs the risk of getting us sucked into perpetual warfare in that region.Thirdly
column363: when we talk about Syria right now
column367: Assad is another brutal murdering dictator
column368: but right now our fight is to destroy ISIS first
column369: and to get rid of Assad second.CLINTON: Well
column370: I think Senator Sanders has just reinforced my point. Yes
column371: when I was secretary of state I did urge
column372: along with the Department of Defense and the CIA that we seek out
column375: and arm Syrian opposition figures so that they could defend themselves against Assad.The president said no. Now
column376: thats how it works. People who work for the president make recommendations and then the president makes the decision. So I think its only fair to look at where we are in Syria today.And
column378: I do still support a no-fly zone because I think we need to put in safe havens for those poor Syrians who are fleeing both Assad and ISIS and have some place that they can be safe.BLITZER: Staying on national security
column379: Dana Bash has a question.BASH: Senator Sanders
column383: quote: It is not the time to continue wasting tens of billions of dollars helping to defend Europe
column384: let alone assuming more than our share of any cost associated with expanding NATO.Do you still feel that way?SANDERS: Well
column386: if my memory is correct here
column387: we spend about 75 percent of the entire cost of the military aspect of NATO. Given the fact that France has a very good health care system and free public education
column389: the U.K. has a good National Health Service and they also provide fairly reasonable higher education
column392: I do believe that the countries of Europe should pick up more of the burden for their defense. Yes
column393: I do.(APPLAUSE)BASH: And just following up
column395: Donald Trump also argues that NATO is unfair economically to the U.S. because America pays a disproportionate share. So how is what you say about NATO and your proposal different than his?SANDERS: Well
column396: you got to ask  you got to ask Trump. All I can tell you is
column398: with 47 million people living in poverty
column401: I do think countries like Germany and U.K. and France and European countries whose economy
column402: or at least its standard of living and health care and education
column403: theyre doing pretty well.So I would not be embarrassed as president of the United States to stay to our European allies
column405: the United States of America cannot just support your economies. You got to put up your own fair share of the defense burden. Nothing wrong with that.(APPLAUSE)BASH: Secretary Clinton?CLINTON: I support our continuing involvement in NATO. And it is important to ask for our NATO allies to pay more of the cost. There is a requirement that they should be doing so
column406: and I believe that needs to be enforced.But theres a larger question here. NATO has been the most successful military alliance in probably human history. It has bound together across the Atlantic countries that are democracies
column407: that have many of the same values and interests
column408: and now we need to modernize it and move it into the 21st century to serve as that head of our defense operations in Europe when it comes to terrorism and other threats that we face. So...BASH: But
column410: of course they should be paying more
column411: but that doesnt mean if they dont we leave
column412: because I dont think thats in Americas interests.BASH: Thats going to be part of my  my question to you is
column414: there are 28 countries in the alliance
column415: and the United States gives more money to NATOs budget than 21 of those countries combined. If they dont agree to pay more
column417: then what would you do as commander-in-chief?CLINTON: I will stay in NATO. I will stay in NATO
column418: and we will continue to look for missions and other kinds of programs that they will support. Remember
column419: NATO was with us in Afghanistan. Most of the member countries also lost soldiers and civilians in Afghanistan. They came to our rallying defense after 9/11. That meant a lot.And
column421: we have to work out the financial aspects of it
column422: but lets not forget whats really happening. With Russia being more aggressive
column423: making all kinds of intimidating moves toward the Baltic countries
column424: weve seen what theyve done in Eastern Ukraine
column425: we know how they want to rewrite the map of Europe
column426: it is not in our interests. Think of how much it would cost if Russias aggression were not deterred because NATO was there on the front lines making it clear they could not move forward.(APPLAUSE)BLITZER: Thank you
column428: lets talk about the U.S. relationship with Israel. Senator Sanders

column432: as somebody who spent many months of my life when I was a kid in Israel
column434: of course Israel has a right not only to defend themselves
column435: but to live in peace and security without fear of terrorist attack. That is not a debate.(APPLAUSE)But  but what you just read
column437: I do believe that. Israel was subjected to terrorist attacks
column438: has every right in the world to destroy terrorism. But we had in the Gaza area  not a very large area  some 10
column439: 000 civilians who were wounded and some 1
column440: 500 who were killed.AUDIENCE MEMBER: Free Palestine!SANDERS: Now
column441: if youre asking not just me
column442: but countries all over the world was that a disproportionate attack
column443: the answer is that I believe it was
column444: and let me say something else.(APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)SANDERS: And
column445: let me say something else. As somebody who is 100% pro-Israel
column446: in the long run  and this is not going to be easy
column448: but in the long run if we are ever going to bring peace to that region which has seen so much hatred and so much war
column449: we are going to have to treat the Palestinian people with respect and dignity.(APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)SANDERS: So what is not to say  to say that right now in Gaza
column450: right now in Gaza unemployment is s somewhere around 40%. You got a log of that area continues
column454: schools decimated. I believe the United States and the rest of the world have got to work together to help the Palestinian people.That does not make me anti-Israel. That paves the way
column456: Senator...SANDERS: ...to an approach that works in the Middle East.(APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)BLITZER: Thank you. Secretary Clinton
column457: do you agree with Senator Sanders that Israel overreacts to Palestinians attacks
column458: and that in order for there to be peace between Israel and the Palestinians
column461: end its disproportionate responses?CLINTON: I negotiated the cease-fire between Israel and Hamas in November of 2012. I did it in concert with...(APPLAUSE)CLINTON: President Abbas of the Palestinian authority based in Ramallah
column462: I did it with the then Muslim Brotherhood President
column465: working closely with Prime Minister Netanyahu and the Israeli cabinet. I can tell you right now I have been there with Israeli officials going back more than 25 years that they do not seek this kind of attacks. They do not invite the rockets raining down on their towns and villages.(APPLAUSE)They do not believe that there should be a constant incitement by Hamas aided and abetted by Iran against Israel. And
column466: so when it came time after they had taken the incoming rockets
column467: taken the assaults and ambushes on their soldiers and they called and told me
column469: that they were getting ready to have to invade Gaza again because they couldnt find anybody to talk to tell them to stop it
column473: I dont know how you run a country when you are under constant threat
column475: rockets coming at you. You have a right to defend yourself.(APPLAUSE)That does not mean  that does not mean that you dont take appropriate precautions. And
column476: I understand that theres always second guessing anytime there is a war. It also does not mean that we should not continue to do everything we can to try to reach a two-state solution
column477: which would give the Palestinians the rights and...BLITZER: ... Thank you...CLINTON: ... just let me finish. The rights and the autonomy that they deserve. And
column479: if Yasser Arafat had agreed with my husband at Camp David in the Late 1990s to the offer then Prime Minister Barat put on the table
column480: we would have had a Palestinian state for 15 years.(APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)BLITZER: Thank you
column483: Senator.SANDERS: I dont think that anybody would suggest that Israel invites and welcomes missiles flying into their country. That is not the issue.And

column783: youre first.SANDERS: I grew up in Brooklyn

And I disagree with Secretary Clinton in the belief that you can get money from Wall Street

column798: and create a government that works for all of us
column799: not just the 1 percent.(APPLAUSE)That is what the political revolution is about. That is what this campaign is about. And with your help
column800: were going to win here in New York. Thank you. Thank you.(APPLAUSE)BLITZER: Secretary Clinton? Secretary Clinton?CLINTON: Thank you. I am very grateful for the fact that the people of New York gave me the great honor of serving as your senator. You took a chance on me in 2000
column801: and then you re-elected me with one of the biggest margins weve had in our state in 2006. During those years
column802: we worked closely together. I tried to have your back
column804: you had mine.We took on the challenges of 9/11 together. We got the money to rebuild New York. We came to the aid of our brave first responders
